      "An
a reversible loss of sensation. They are broadly classified into general anesthetics, which cause a reversible loss of consciousness,

and local anesthetics, which block nerve transmission in a specific region of the body.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • General Anesthetics: Induce a state of unconsciousness, analgesia, am
nesia, and muscle relaxation. They can be inhaled (e.g., sevoflurane, desflurane
) or intravenous (e.g., propofol, ketamine, etomidate). Their potency is measured by the <

mark>Minimum Alveolar Concentration (MAC).
  • Local Anesthetics: Block nerve conduction by inhibiting
voltage-gated Na<sup>+</sup> channels. They are classified as esters (e.g., procaine, cocaine
) or amides (e.g., lidocaine, bupivacaine). They are weak bases and are less

effective in infected (acidic) tissue.
  • Neuromuscular Blockers: Often used with general anesthetics to achieve
profound muscle relaxation (paralysis). They can be depolarizing (e.g., succinylcholine) or non-depolarizing (e.g

., rocuronium).
  • Malignant Hyperthermia: A rare, life-threatening hypermetabolic state
triggered by inhaled anesthetics (except N<sub>2</sub>O) and succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals. Treated with [[

dantrolene]].
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the key pharmacokinetic properties of inhaled anesthetics: low
blood solubility (low blood:gas partition coefficient) leads to rapid induction and recovery, while high lipid solubility (high oil

:gas partition coefficient) corresponds to high potency (low MAC).", "takeAway": "

The
field of anesthesia relies on a combination of drugs to achieve a balanced state of unconsciousness, analgesia,
and muscle relaxation, with general anesthetics acting on the CNS to induce sleep and local anesthetics acting on peripheral nerves to block pain

      "C
erebral aneurysms are localized, abnormal dilations of blood vessels in the brain, which carry a significant risk of rupture, leading to life

-threatening intracranial hemorrhage.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Saccular (Berry) Aneurysms:
Most common type. Thin-walled outpouchings, typically occurring at arterial branch points in the [[e223
00e8|Circle of Willis]]. Most common site is the junction of the [[bd802d2
2|anterior communicating artery]] and anterior cerebral artery. Rupture causes [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage

]].
  • Associations with Saccular Aneurysms: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (

ADPKD), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, hypertension, smoking.
  • Char
cot-Bouchard Microaneurysms: Aneurysms of small, penetrating arteries (e.g., lent
iculostriate arteries) associated with chronic hypertension. Rupture causes [[70b266c8|

intraparenchymal hemorrhage]], typically in deep brain structures like the basal ganglia or thalamus.
  • R
upture Presentation: Rupture of a saccular aneurysm classically presents as a sudden, severe \"worst
headache of my life\"</mark> (thunderclap headache), indicating a [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid

hemorrhage]].
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with ADPKD who develops a sudden, severe headache should
be immediately evaluated for a ruptured berry aneurysm. A PCom aneurysm can compress CN III, causing a 'down and out' eye

definition": "

Angle-closure glaucoma is an ophthalmologic emergency characterized by a sudden, severe increase in intra
ocular pressure (IOP) due to the physical obstruction of aqueous humor outflow through the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral

iris.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Pathophysiology: Occurs in individuals
with a pre-existing narrow anterior chamber angle. Pupillary dilation (mydriasis) causes the peripheral iris to bunch up and block the trab

ecular meshwork, acutely halting aqueous humor drainage.
  • Triggers: Any event causing mydriasis can
trigger an attack, such as entering a dark room, stress, or administration of sympathomimetic or anticholinergic drugs.
• Clinical Presentation: Sudden onset of severe, unilateral eye pain, headache, nausea/

vomiting, and blurred vision with halos around lights.
  • Physical Exam: The eye
is red and hard to palpation ('rock hard'). The pupil is typically <mark>mid-dilated and non

reactive to light. The cornea may appear hazy or steamy.
  • USMLE Tip: This is a true
ophthalmic emergency. The classic presentation of a painful, red eye with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil and halos around

lights is pathognomonic.", "takeAway": "

Angle-closure glaucoma
is a mechanical plumbing problem of the eye where pupillary dilation in a predisposed individual causes the iris to act like a drain

plug, leading to a rapid and painful spike in intraocular pressure that threatens vision.

", "mermaid":
"graph TD; A[Predisposing Narrow Angle] --Pupillary Dilation--> B(Iris bunches at periphery); B --> C(Blocks
Trabecular Meshwork); C --> D(‚Üì Aqueous Outflow); D --> E(‚Üë‚Üë Intraocular Pressure);

"content": { "definition": "

Anhidrosis, the inability to sweat normally, is one
of the three classic signs of [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]], resulting from the disruption

of sympathetic innervation to the sweat glands of the face.

", "atAGlance": "
Horner Syndrome Triad: The full triad is Ptosis (mild eyelid droop), Miosis (

constricted pupil), and Anhidrosis (decreased sweating).
  • Mechanism: Disruption of the o
culosympathetic pathway prevents the release of acetylcholine from postganglionic sympathetic neurons that innervate sweat glands (a sympathetic

exception).
  • Localization Value: The distribution of anhidrosis can help localize the lesion in the three-neuron

sympathetic chain.
  • Lesion Localization:
    - 1st Order (Central): Lesion in

hypothalamus or brainstem/spinal cord. Anhidrosis affects the entire ipsilateral half of the body.
- 2nd Order
(Preganglionic): Lesion in the chest (e.g., Pancoast tumor). Anhidrosis affects the ipsilateral face and

neck.
- 3rd Order (Postganglionic): Lesion above the superior cervical ganglion (e.g., carotid
dissection). Anhidrosis is often minimal or absent, affecting only a small patch on the forehead, because fibers to most

facial sweat glands travel with the external carotid artery.
  • USMLE Tip: A painful Horner syndrome (especially
with neck pain) should raise suspicion for a carotid artery dissection, a 3rd order neuron lesion where anhidrosis is often absent.

", "takeAway": "

While part of the classic triad, the presence and distribution of anhid
rosis in [[c19010a3|Horner syndrome]] is a subtle but powerful clue for
localizing the lesion along the long oculosympathetic pathway, with widespread anhidrosis suggesting a central lesion and absent anhidrosis pointing

towards a postganglionic (3rd order) problem.

definition": "

The Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA) is a major artery of the brain that branches

from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, as well as the corpus callosum.

", "

atAGlance": "
  • Origin: Arises from the bifurcation of the internal carotid artery. The left
and right ACAs are connected by the [[bd802d22|anterior communicating artery]].
Territory Supplied: Supplies the medial surface of the cerebral hemispheres. Based on the motor and sensory homunculus, this corresponds to the

lower extremities.
  • Stroke Syndrome: Occlusion of the ACA results in a characteristic
stroke syndrome with <mark>contralateral motor and sensory deficits predominantly affecting the lower limb</mark> (leg >

arm/face).
  • Other Stroke Signs: May also cause urinary incontinence due to damage to the paracentral lobule

. Frontal lobe signs like abulia (lack of will/initiative) or personality changes can occur.
  • USMLE Tip:
The key to identifying an ACA stroke is the disproportionate weakness and sensory loss in the contralateral leg compared to the arm and
face. This contrasts sharply with an [[143bb23d|MCA stroke]].", "takeAway

": "

The Anterior Cerebral Artery is responsible for the medial brain territory, meaning its occlusion
uniquely manifests as a stroke that 'kicks the leg out' from under the patient, with motor and sensory deficits primarily

affecting the contralateral lower extremity.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Internal Carotid Artery] --> B(
Anterior Cerebral Artery); B --> C(Supplies Medial Cortex); C --> D(Motor/Sensory Hom

"Anterior Circulation Strokes",

      "Pathology",
Anterior circulation strokes are ischemic events caused by occlusion of the internal carotid artery or its major branches, the [[
830c856c|anterior cerebral artery (ACA)]] and the [[143bb23d

|middle cerebral artery (MCA)]], leading to deficits related to the cerebral hemispheres.

", "atAG

lance": "
  • Vessels Involved: Internal carotid artery (ICA), [[143bb23d|Middle
Cerebral Artery (MCA)]], [[830c856c|Anterior Cerebral Artery (ACA

)]].
  • MCA Stroke: The most common type of ischemic stroke. Presents with contralateral hem
iparesis and sensory loss affecting the face and upper limb more than the lower limb</mark>. If the dominant (
usually left) hemisphere is affected, it causes [[6bc9a567|aphasia]] (Broca's or W

ernicke's). If the non-dominant hemisphere is affected, it causes hemineglect.
  • ACA
Stroke: Presents with contralateral hemiparesis and sensory loss affecting the lower limb more than the upper limb</

mark>. May also cause urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs (e.g., personality changes, abulia).
  • Dist
inction: The key differentiator is the distribution of weakness based on the homunculus: MCA strokes affect the face/arm, while ACA strokes affect the leg

.
  • USMLE Tip: Aphasia is a 'cortical sign' that strongly points to an
MCA stroke in the dominant hemisphere. Leg weakness greater than arm weakness is the classic sign of an ACA stroke.", "takeAway

": "

Anterior circulation strokes produce deficits that can be precisely localized by understanding the functional anatomy of the cerebral cortex

and the homunculus; MCA strokes paralyze the contralateral face and arm, while ACA strokes paralyze the contralateral leg.

", "mermaid
": "graph TD; A[Internal Carotid Artery] --> B(MCA); B --> C(Contralateral Face
/Arm Deficits, Aphasia/Neglect); A --> D(ACA); D --> E(Contralateral

ComA)",

"Neurology and Special Senses",
      "Anatomy and Physiology",
      "Cerebral Vascul
(AComA) is a short blood vessel that connects the left and right [[830c856c|
anterior cerebral arteries]], forming the anterior aspect of the [[e22300e8|Circle of Willis]].</

p>", "atAGlance": "
  • Function: Provides collateral blood flow between the two anterior

cerebral circulations.
  • Clinical Significance: It is the most common site for the formation of sacc

ular (berry) aneurysms in the brain.
  • Aneurysm Complications:
    1
. Rupture: Leads to [[63f8b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]],

presenting as a \"worst headache of my life.\"
2. Compression: A large, un
ruptured aneurysm can compress the adjacent <mark>optic chiasm</mark>, causing a [[6c3a9

80e|bitemporal hemianopia]] (tunnel vision).
  • USMLE Tip: When
a question mentions a saccular aneurysm, the AComA should be the first location you consider. If the patient has
visual field defects, especially bitemporal hemianopia, an AComA aneurysm is a very likely cause.

", "takeAway": "

The Anterior Communicating Artery, while
small, is clinically significant as the number one location for berry aneurysms, which can either rupture catastrophically into

the subarachnoid space or compress the optic chiasm, causing tunnel vision.

", "mermaid
": "graph TD; A[Left ACA] -- AComA --> B[Right ACA]; C(ACom
A Aneurysm) --> D(Rupture -> SAH); C --> E(Compression -> Bitemporal Hemianopia);"

": "

The Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (AICA) is an artery in
the brain that arises from the basilar artery and supplies blood to the anterior inferior portion of the cerebellum, as well as parts of the lateral

pons.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Origin: Typically arises from the lower third

of the basilar artery.
  • Territory Supplied: Lateral pons, middle and inferior cerebellar peduncles, and the

anterior inferior cerebellum. It also gives rise to the labyrinthine artery in most individuals, which supplies the inner ear.
  • Stroke Syndrome

: Occlusion of the AICA causes Lateral Pontine Syndrome.
  • Symptoms of A
ICA Stroke: Mnemonic AICA: Ataxia (ipsilateral, from cerebellar
peduncle damage), Ipsilateral facial paralysis (CN VII nucleus/fibers) and deafness/vertigo (CN VIII nucleus/labyrinth
ine artery), Contralateral pain/temp loss (spinothalamic tract), A

utonomic signs (ipsilateral Horner syndrome).
  • USMLE Tip: The key to distinguishing an AICA stroke from a
PICA stroke (Lateral Medullary Syndrome) is the presence of <mark>facial paralysis</mark> and <mark>de
afness, which are specific to the pontine location of the AICA territory.", "take

Away": "

Occlusion of the Anterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery results in Lateral Pontine Syndrome, a
complex brainstem stroke characterized by a unique combination of cerebellar signs, contralateral body sensory loss, and ipsilateral facial deficits including

paralysis and deafness, which localizes the lesion squarely to the lateral pons.

", "mermaid": "graph TD
; A[Basilar Artery] --> B(AICA); B --> C(Lateral Pons); B --> D(An
terior Inferior Cerebellum); B --> E(Labyrinthine Artery); C --> F(CN VII & VIII Nucle

      "
Anterior Nucleus is a region of the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]]
that plays a primary role in thermoregulation, specifically in dissipating heat to cool the body. It is part of the parasympathetic nervous system.</p

>", "atAGlance": "
  • Function: Mediates heat dissipation (cooling). M
nemonic: The A/C (Anterior Cooling) is in

the front of the house.
  • Mechanism: Senses when the body is too hot and initiates parasympathetic responses like

cutaneous vasodilation and sweating to promote heat loss.
  • Lesion Effect: A lesion in the anterior

nucleus results in hyperthermia, as the body loses its ability to cool itself down.
  • Counterpart:
The [[posterior_nucleus_of_hypothalamus|posterior nucleus of the hypothalamus]] is responsible for heat conservation and

production (heating).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember the functional pairing: Anterior hypothalamus = Cooling (parasympathetic),
Posterior hypothalamus = Heating (sympathetic). A lesion in the anterior nucleus leads to an inability to cool down.", "takeAway

": "

The Anterior Nucleus of the hypothalamus functions as the body's thermostat for cooling; its

destruction leads to uncontrolled hyperthermia because the primary mechanism for heat dissipation is lost.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A
[‚Üë Body Temperature] --> B(Anterior Nucleus); B --Parasympathetic Output--> C(Cutaneous Vasodilation & Sweating);

)",

>The Anterior Spinal Artery (ASA) is a major artery that supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal

cord. It originates from the vertebral arteries in the cranium and descends along the anterior surface of the spinal cord.

", "at

AGlance": "
  • Origin: Formed from the union of two branches of the vertebral arteries.
  • Territory Supplied

othalamic tracts, and the anterior horns. It notably <u>spares</u> the [[e7f5cb

be|dorsal columns]].
  • Stroke Syndrome (Spinal Cord): Occlusion causes [[
b48b54d7|Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome]]</mark>, characterized by bilateral loss of motor function (fl
accid paralysis at the level, UMN signs below) and pain/temperature sensation below the level of the lesion, with

preserved proprioception and vibration sense.
  • Stroke Syndrome (Medulla): Occlusion of param

edian branches of the ASA or vertebral arteries causes Medial Medullary Syndrome.
  • US
MLE Tip: The key to identifying an ASA stroke is the dissociation of sensory loss: pain and temperature are gone, but
vibration and position sense are intact because the dorsal columns are spared.", "takeAway": "
The Anterior Spinal Artery is the lifeline for the motor and pain/temperature pathways of the spinal cord;
its occlusion creates a devastating syndrome of bilateral paralysis and sensory loss, sparing only the dorsal columns' functions of vibration and proprio

ception.

"content": { "definition": "

Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome is a spinal
cord infarct resulting from occlusion of the [[1430f5b4|anterior spinal artery (ASA)]], which leads

to ischemia of the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, causing a distinct pattern of neurological deficits below the level of the lesion.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Etiology: Caused by occlusion of the ASA,
which can result from aortic surgery (e.g., repair of an aneurysm), severe hypotension (watershed infarct), or thrombo

embolism.
  • Structures Damaged: Corticospinal tracts, spinothalamic tracts, and anterior

horns.
  • Structures Spared: The [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]]

are spared due to their separate blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    -
Motor: Bilateral flaccid paralysis at the level of the lesion (LMN signs from anterior horn damage) and bilateral

spastic paralysis below the lesion (UMN signs from corticospinal tract damage).
- Sensory: Bil

ateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion (spinothalamic tract damage).
- S
ensation Preserved: Proprioception, vibration, and fine touch are intact because the dorsal columns are

spared.
  • USMLE Tip: The dissociation between loss of pain/temperature and preservation of vibration/proprioception is

the pathognomonic feature of this syndrome.", "takeAway": "

Anterior Spinal Artery Syndrome
creates a stark neurological divide, paralyzing the body and eliminating pain and temperature sensation below the lesion, while leaving the sense

of position and vibration completely intact, a direct reflection of the spinal cord's vascular territories.

", "mermaid":
"graph TD; A[ASA Occlusion] --> B(Infarct of Anterior 2/3 of Spinal Cord); B

": { "definition": "

Anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies are a class of medications used for
the prophylactic treatment of [[c8833bae|migraine headaches]]. They work by targeting either calcitonin gene-related peptide

(CGRP) itself or its receptor, which are key players in the pathophysiology of migraines.

", "atAG

lance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: These monoclonal antibodies bind to either the CGRP ligand (e.g., e
ptinezumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab) or the CGRP receptor (e.g.,
erenumab), preventing CGRP from mediating its effects of vasodilation and pain transmission in the trigeminal nervous

system.
  • Clinical Use: Used for the prevention (prophylaxis) of episodic

and chronic [[c8833bae|migraines]]. They are not used for acute treatment.
  • Administration

: Administered via subcutaneous injection or IV infusion, typically on a monthly or quarterly basis.
  • Adverse Effects: Generally well-toler
ated. The most common side effects are injection site reactions. Constipation is notably associated with the CGRP receptor antagonists (e.g., erenumab

).
  • USMLE Tip: Recognize these drugs by their '-mab' suffix and their specific use for
migraine prophylaxis. They represent a targeted therapy based on the modern understanding of migraine pathophysiology involving CGRP.",

"takeAway": "

Anti-CGRP monoclonal antibodies represent a major advance in migraine prevention, offering
a highly specific mechanism that directly neutralizes the CGRP pathway, a key driver of pain and inflammation in migraine attacks.</

p>",
      "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Trigeminal Nerve Activation] --> B(Release of CGRP); B --> C(
CGRP Receptor); C --> D(Vasodilation & Pain Transmission); D --> E(Migraine); F[Anti-CGRP mAbs

e045|Valproate]], [[08d19a8f|Lamotrigine]].
2. Enhancement of GABAergic inhibition: Benzodiazepines, Barbiturates, [[val

proic_acid|Valproate]].
3. Ca2+ Channel Blockade:
[[a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] (T-type), Gabapentinoids

.

    - Broad-spectrum: [[valproic_acid|Valproic
acid]], [[08d19a8f|lamotrigine]], [[2341f9
c0|levetiracetam]], [[e1f5066c|topiramate]]. Effective

for both focal and generalized seizures.
- Narrow-spectrum: [[eddd2bc5|Carbamaz
epine]], [[5aea213f|phenytoin]], gabapentinoids. Primarily for focal seizures. [[

a90f6fb4|Ethosuximide]] is for absence seizures only.
  • Other Uses
: Many anticonvulsants are also used for bipolar disorder, neuropathic pain, and [[c8833bae|migraine

]] prophylaxis. Some are used in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] for symptomatic treatment.
  • Adverse Effects:
Common side effects include sedation, dizziness, and ataxia. Many carry a risk of serious skin reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome (

SJS), especially lamotrigine and carbamazepine. All are potentially teratogenic.
  • US
MLE Tip: Know the first-line treatments for specific seizure types: Absence -> [[a90f6fb4|Eth
osuximide]]; Tonic-clonic -> [[valproic_acid|Valproic acid]], [[2341f9c0|

levetiracetam]]; Status epilepticus -> Benzodiazepines.", "takeAway": "

ulsants primarily work by either dampening neuronal excitability (e.g., blocking Na+ channels) or enhancing

      "Hypothalamic-Pituitary Axis
ADH), also known as vasopressin, is a peptide hormone synthesized in the [[89e866
33|hypothalamus]] and released from the posterior pituitary. Its primary functions are to regulate plasma osmolality by

increasing water reabsorption in the kidneys and to regulate blood pressure via vasoconstriction.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Synthesis
& Release: Synthesized primarily in the supraoptic nucleus of the [[89e86633
|hypothalamus]], transported down axons, and stored/released from the posterior pituitary (neurohypophysis).
Regulation: Release is stimulated by increased plasma osmolality (detected by osmoreceptors

in the hypothalamus) and, to a lesser extent, by decreased blood volume/pressure.
  • Renal Action
(V2 Receptors): Binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membrane of principal cells in the renal
collecting ducts. This activates a G<sub>s</sub>-cAMP pathway, leading to the insertion of <mark>aquaporin-2</

mark> channels into the apical membrane, increasing water reabsorption.
  • Vascular Action (V1 Receptors): B
inds to V1 receptors on vascular smooth muscle, activating a G<sub>q</sub>-IP<sub>3</sub>/DAG pathway that

causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: Pathologies are key: Deficiency of ADH or
its receptor causes [[diabetes_insipidus]]. Excess ADH secretion causes [[syndrome_of_inappropriate_antidiuretic_horm

one|SIADH]].", "takeAway": "

Antidiuretic Hormone is
the body's primary regulator of water balance, acting on the kidney's collecting ducts via V2 receptors to conserve

water when osmolality is high, and on blood vessels via V1 receptors to raise blood pressure when volume is low.

", "

": { "definition": "

Antimuscarinic drugs, also known as anticholinergics,
are a class of medications that act as competitive antagonists at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, thereby blocking the effects of the parasympathetic nervous system.</

p>", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: Competitively block [[6a
005559|acetylcholine]] at muscarinic receptors (M1, M2, M3

). They do not affect nicotinic receptors.
  • Clinical Effects (Mnemonic): \"Hot as a hare, dry

as a bone, blind as a bat, red as a beet, mad as a hatter.\"
-

Dry: ‚Üì Salivation, lacrimation, sweating.
- Blind: M

ydriasis (pupil dilation) and cycloplegia (loss of accommodation).
- Hot

& Red: ‚Üì Sweating leads to hyperthermia and compensatory flushing.
- Mad: CNS

effects like delirium, confusion, hallucinations (especially with drugs that cross the BBB).
  • Neurologic Use: Used in [[
58c8ea03|Parkinson disease]] (e.g., [[383f6fbe|benztrop
ine]], trihexyphenidyl) to treat tremor and rigidity by rebalancing the cholinergic-dopaminergic systems

. Also used to treat drug-induced extrapyramidal symptoms.
  • Other Uses: Atropine (br
adycardia), scopolamine (motion sickness), ipratropium (COPD), oxybutynin (over

active bladder).
  • USMLE Tip: Be cautious using antimuscarinics in the elderly due to increased
risk of confusion, hallucinations, and delirium. They are contraindicated in [[9c80344d|angle

-closure glaucoma]].", "takeAway": "

Antimuscarinic drugs function
by blocking the 'rest and digest' functions of the parasympathetic nervous system, leading to a predictable constellation of side effects that

are essentially the opposite of a cholinergic toxidrome.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Acetyl
choline] --x B(Antimuscarinic Drugs); B --x C(Muscarinic Receptors); C --

"content": { "definition": "

Antispasmodics, or skeletal muscle relaxants, are a group
of drugs used to alleviate symptoms associated with muscle spasticity or acute muscle spasms by acting either on the central nervous system or

directly on the muscle.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Baclofen: A [[
gaba_b_receptor|GABA<sub>B</sub> receptor]] agonist that acts on the spinal cord to suppress hyper

active reflexes. Used for spasticity in [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]] and spinal cord injury.
  • Cyclobenz
aprine: A centrally acting muscle relaxant, structurally related to TCAs. Used for acute muscle spasms from musculoskeletal

conditions. Has significant anticholinergic side effects and causes sedation.
  • Tizanidine: A centrally acting Œ±2-adrenergic agonist
that inhibits motor neuron activity. Used for spasticity. Can cause hypotension, sedation, and dry mouth.
Dantrolene: Acts directly on skeletal muscle by blocking Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (
inhibits ryanodine receptor). <u>Used to treat malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome</u>.
• USMLE Tip: Differentiate the uses: [[baclofen]] and tizanidine for chronic spasticity (
MS, spinal cord injury), cyclobenzaprine for acute muscle strain, and [[dantrolene]] for life

-threatening hyperthermic syndromes.", "takeAway": "

Antispasmodics reduce
muscle hyperactivity through diverse mechanisms, ranging from central GABAergic and adrenergic modulation (baclofen, tizanidine) to

direct interference with muscle contraction machinery (dantrolene), the latter being crucial for treating hyperthermic emergencies.

",

      "Path
are a group of mental health conditions characterized by excessive and persistent fear, anxiety, or worry that is disproportionate to the situation and impairs
daily functioning. They are associated with altered activity in brain circuits involving the [[d220fc3f|amygdala]] and pre

frontal cortex.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Neurotransmitter Imbalance: Associated with decreased
levels of [[5d3c2089|serotonin]] and [[gaba|GABA]], and

increased levels of norepinephrine.
  • Common Types:
    - Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Chronic

, uncontrollable worry about multiple issues.
- Panic Disorder: Recurrent, unexpected panic attacks.
- Ph

obias: Intense, irrational fear of a specific object or situation.
- Social Anxiety Disorder: Fear

of social situations and scrutiny.
  • First-Line Treatment: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and/

or SSRIs/SNRIs are the first-line treatments for most anxiety disorders.
  • Second
-Line/Adjunctive Treatment: [[14464617|Benzodiazepines]] (e.g., [[0
83094db|alprazolam]], lorazepam) are used for rapid relief of acute anxiety or panic attacks but are
not preferred for long-term use due to dependence risk. Buspirone is a non-sedating anxiolytic used

for GAD.
  • USMLE Tip: For long-term management of anxiety, SSRIs/SNRIs are preferred
. Benzodiazepines are for short-term or 'as-needed' use.", "takeAway

": "

Anxiety disorders represent a dysregulation of the brain's fear and worry circuits, driven
by an imbalance of key neurotransmitters. Modern treatment focuses on long-term modulation with SSRIs/SNRIs and CBT

, reserving fast-acting benzodiazepines for acute, short-term management.

": "

Aphasia is an acquired language disorder resulting from damage to the language centers of the brain, typically in the dominant
(usually left) hemisphere. It affects the ability to produce and/or comprehend spoken or written language, and is distinct from dys

arthria (a motor speech disorder).

", "atAGlance": "
  • Broca's Aphasia (
Expressive): Lesion in the inferior frontal gyrus ([[a3bbace2|Broca's area
]]). Characterized by <mark>nonfluent, telegraphic speech</mark> with intact comprehension. Patients are often frustrated
by their inability to speak. Mnemonic: Broca's is Broken

Boca (mouth).
  • Wernicke's Aphasia (Receptive): Les
ion in the superior temporal gyrus ([[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]]). Characterized by <mark>fluent
but meaningless speech (word salad) with severely impaired comprehension. Patients are often unaware of their deficit (anosognosia).
• Conduction Aphasia: Lesion of the arcuate fasciculus,

which connects Broca's and Wernicke's areas. Hallmark is poor repetition despite fluent speech and intact comprehension.
  • Global
Aphasia: Large lesion affecting both Broca's and Wernicke's areas, typically from a large [[

143bb23d|MCA stroke]]. All language functions (fluency, comprehension, repetition) are severely impaired.
  • US
MLE Tip: The most common cause of aphasia is an ischemic [[c5da3c57|stroke]] in the territory
of the left [[143bb23d|Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA)]].", "takeAway":

"

Aphasia is a disorder of language, not speech mechanics, with distinct subtypes that can be precisely localized within
the dominant cerebral hemisphere: Broca's area for production, Wernicke's area for comprehension, and the arcuate fascicul

us for repetition.

ernicke's - Fluent, Poor Comprehension]; B --> E[Conduction - Poor Repetition]; B --> F[Global - All

      "Path
optosis is a form of programmed cell death that is a highly regulated and controlled process, essential for normal tissue turnover, embryonic
development, and removal of damaged or infected cells. In the context of neurology, it is the primary mechanism of neuronal death

in many neurodegenerative diseases.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Key Features: Character
ized by cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation (pyknosis), membrane blebbing, and formation of apoptotic bodies, which are then phagocytosed.

It is an ATP-dependent process and does not induce inflammation.
  • Pathways:<
br> - Intrinsic (Mitochondrial): Activated by cellular stress (e.g., DNA damage,
misfolded proteins). Regulated by the Bcl-2 family of proteins. Pro-apoptotic proteins (Bax, Bak

) create pores in the mitochondrial membrane, releasing cytochrome c, which activates caspases.
- Extrinsic (
Death Receptor): Activated by external ligands (e.g., FasL, TNF-Œ±) binding to death receptors on the cell surface,

directly activating caspases.
  • Caspases: The central executioners of apoptosis are a family of cysteine proteases called

caspases, which orchestrate the degradation of cellular components.
  • Neurologic Relevance: Apoptosis of
lower motor neurons is a key feature of [[4ed629f9|Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)]].
It is also the mechanism of neuronal loss in [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]] and [[58c8ea03|

Parkinson disease]].
  • USMLE Tip: Contrast apoptosis with necrosis. Necrosis is uncontrolled cell death due
to injury, causing cell swelling, membrane rupture, and inflammation. Apoptosis is clean, programmed, and non-inflammatory.

", "takeAway": "

Apoptosis is the cell's intrinsic suicide program
, executed by caspases, which neatly packages the cell for disposal without triggering an inflammatory response; its dysregulation is a central

theme in both cancer (too little apoptosis) and neurodegeneration (too much apoptosis).

", "mermaid": "graph TD
; A{Cellular Stress} --> B(Intrinsic Pathway); B --> C(Mitochondria); C --Cy
tochrome c--> D; E{Death Ligands} --> F(Extrinsic Pathway); F --> D(Caspase Activation); D --> G(

{ "definition": "

Apraclonidine is an Œ±2-adrenergic agonist
used topically in ophthalmology to lower intraocular pressure (IOP), primarily for the short-term treatment of [[3

ce6c035|glaucoma]].

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism
of Action: As a selective Œ±2-agonist, it acts on presynaptic Œ±2 receptors
in the ciliary body to <mark>decrease aqueous humor synthesis</mark>. It also has some minor effect on increasing uve

oscleral outflow.
  • Clinical Use: Used to lower IOP in patients with [[5ea7b7
41|open-angle glaucoma]]. It is particularly useful for preventing post-surgical IOP spikes. Its use is often

limited to the short term due to tachyphylaxis (diminishing response).
  • Adverse Effects: O
cular side effects include blurry vision, ocular hyperemia (redness), foreign body sensation, and ocular allergic reactions. Systemic side

effects are rare but can include dry mouth and fatigue.
  • Comparison: Similar to [[brimonidine]],
another Œ±2-agonist used for glaucoma, but apraclonidine has a higher rate of tachyphylaxis and allergic reactions.
USMLE Tip: Remember that Œ±2-agonists (like apraclonidine and clonidine) work
by reducing sympathetic outflow. In the eye, this translates to decreased production of aqueous humor.", "takeAway

": "

Apraclonidine lowers intraocular pressure by acting as a 'brake' on aqueous humor production
, stimulating Œ±<sub>2</sub>-receptors in the ciliary body to reduce fluid synthesis, making it a useful agent

for short-term management of glaucoma.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Apraclonidine] --> B(Stim
ulates Œ±2 Receptors in Ciliary Body); B --> C(‚Üì Norepinephrine Release); C --> D(‚Üì Aqueous

"type": "is_a_type_of",

"content": { "definition": "

Gait apraxia is a high-level gait
disorder characterized by the inability to properly coordinate the motor sequences for walking, despite having normal motor, sensory, and cerebellar function. It is often

described as a \"magnetic gait,\" where the feet appear stuck to the floor.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients have difficulty initiating walking. The gait is wide-based, shuffling, and slow,

with the feet barely leaving the ground. Turning is particularly difficult and requires multiple small steps.
  • Pathophysiology: It

is considered a disorder of the frontal lobes or their connections, disrupting the cortical control of locomotion.
  • Classic Association
: Gait apraxia is one of the three cardinal signs of [[7c59030

e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)]].
  • NPH Triad: The classic

triad is \"Wobbly, Wacky, and Wet\":
1. Wobbly

: Gait apraxia.
2. Wacky: Cognitive dysfunction/dementia.
3.

Wet: Urinary incontinence.
  • USMLE Tip: The description of a 'magnetic' or '
feet stuck to the floor' gait in an elderly patient, especially when combined with cognitive changes and urinary incontinence, is a
classic vignette for [[7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus]].", "takeAway

": "

Gait apraxia is a 'brain' problem, not a 'leg' problem;
it represents a failure of the frontal lobe's motor programming for walking, famously manifesting as the 'magnetic' gait of [[

7c59030e|Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus]].

", "mermaid": "" }, "connections

"content": { "definition": "

The Aqueous Humor Pathway describes the continuous production,
circulation, and drainage of aqueous humor, the clear fluid that fills the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye. The balance between production and drainage determines

the intraocular pressure (IOP).

", "atAGlance": "
  • Production:
Aqueous humor is produced by the <mark>nonpigmented epithelium of the ciliary body</mark>. This process is decreased

by Œ≤-blockers, Œ±2-agonists, and carbonic anhydrase inhibitors.
  • Circulation: Fluid

flows from the posterior chamber, through the pupil, into the anterior chamber.
  • Drainage Pathways:
    1
. Trabecular Outflow (~90%): Fluid drains through the trabecular meshwork,
into the Canal of Schlemm, and then into the episcleral vasculature. This pathway is enhanced by muscarinic agonists (e.g.,

pilocarpine).
2. Uveoscleral Outflow (~10%): Fluid
drains through the ciliary muscle and into the uveal and scleral tissues. This pathway is enhanced by prostaglandin analogs (e.g.,

latanoprost).
  • Clinical Relevance: Imbalance in this pathway leads to [[3ce6c035|
glaucoma]]. [[5ea7b741|Open-angle glaucoma]] involves increased resistance in the trabecular mesh
work, while [[9c80344d|angle-closure glaucoma]] involves physical obstruction of the angle

.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand how different glaucoma medications target this pathway. Prostaglandins increase uve
oscleral outflow, while Œ≤-blockers and acetazolamide decrease production.", "takeAway":

"

The Aqueous Humor Pathway is a dynamic circulatory system within the eye's anterior segment, where a
delicate equilibrium between ciliary body production and dual-route (trabecular and uveoscleral) drainage is essential for

maintaining normal intraocular pressure.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Ciliary Body Epithelium] --
Produces--> B(Aqueous Humor); B --> C(Posterior Chamber); C --> D(Anterior Chamber); D --> E{
Drainage}; E --> F[Trabecular Outflow (90%)]; F --> G[Canal of Schlemm]; E -->

      "M
ulations (or arachnoid villi) are microscopic protrusions of the [[46e279b9|
arachnoid mater]] through the dura mater into the superior sagittal sinus and other [[21f1c95
5|dural venous sinuses]], functioning as one-way valves for the drainage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the sub

arachnoid space into the venous circulation.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Function:

The primary site for CSF reabsorption into the bloodstream.
  • Mechanism: CSF
flows from the subarachnoid space into the venous sinus down a pressure gradient. The structure acts as a one-way valve,

preventing venous blood from entering the subarachnoid space.
  • Location: Most numerous along the superior sagittal sinus</

mark>.
  • Pathology: Impaired function or obstruction of arachnoid granulations (e.g
., from scarring after meningitis or subarachnoid hemorrhage) can lead to <mark>[[aa4115

c7|communicating hydrocephalus]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that CSF is produced by the chor
oid plexus and reabsorbed by the arachnoid granulations. A problem with reabsorption (communicating hydrocephalus) is
distinct from a blockage of flow within the ventricles (non-communicating hydrocephalus).", "take

Away": "

Arachnoid granulations are the critical drainage ports for cerebrospinal fluid, acting as sophisticated
one-way valves that allow CSF to exit the subarachnoid space and return to the venous system, thereby maintaining intracranial

pressure homeostasis.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Choroid Plexus] --Produces
--> B(CSF); B --> C(Ventricular System); C --> D(Subarachnoid Space); D --> E

(Arachnoid Granulations); E --Reabsorption--> F[Dural Venous Sinuses];"

"definition": "

The Arachnoid Mater is the middle layer of the three meninges that
surround the brain and spinal cord. It is a delicate, avascular membrane located between the outer [[5bbe359

7|dura mater]] and the inner [[pia_mater|pia mater]].

", "atAGlance

": "
  • Structure: Composed of a web-like network of collagen and elastic fibers, from which it gets

its name (from Greek 'arachne' for spider).
  • Embryologic Origin: Derived from the [[1

4c6f2a7|neural crest]].
  • Subarachnoid Space: The space between the arach
noid mater and the pia mater is the <mark>subarachnoid space</mark>, which contains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF

) and major cerebral blood vessels.
  • Arachnoid Granulations: Protrusions of the arachnoid mater

through the dura into the superior sagittal sinus, responsible for CSF reabsorption.
  • Clinical Relevance: Rupture of an
artery in the subarachnoid space (e.g., from a berry aneurysm) causes a [[63f8
b05f|subarachnoid hemorrhage]]. A [[e98ea0ba|meningioma]],

a common benign brain tumor, arises from arachnoid cap cells.", "takeAway": "

The
Arachnoid Mater forms a crucial boundary, creating the subarachnoid space that houses the CSF

and cerebral vasculature, and its specialized granulations are essential for CSF drainage.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Skull
] --> B[Dura Mater]; B --> C(Arachnoid Mater); C --> D[Subarachnoid Space -

"definition": "

The Area Postrema is a highly vascularized structure in the medulla oblongata,
located on the floor of the fourth ventricle, that functions as the <mark>chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ)</mark> for vomiting
. It is one of the circumventricular organs, meaning it lacks a complete [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].

", "atAGlance": "
  • Location: Dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata at

the caudal end of the fourth ventricle.
  • Function: Detects emetogenic toxins in the blood and CSF
and sends signals to the [[74b651ab|vomiting center]] (nucleus tractus solitarius

) to induce emesis (vomiting).
  • Blood-Brain Barrier: Its fenestrated capillaries allow it to directly

sample the chemical composition of the blood.
  • Receptors: Rich in various receptors, including dopamine D
2</sub>, serotonin 5-HT<sub>3</sub>, and neurokinin-1 (NK-1) receptors.
• Clinical Relevance: This is the site of action for many antiemetic drugs. For example, [[
ondansetron]] is a 5-HT<sub>3</sub> antagonist, and [[metoclopramide]] is a D
2 antagonist. It is also the area stimulated by toxins during chemotherapy, leading to chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

", "takeAway": "

The Area Postrema serves as the brain's chemical
surveillance system for the blood; its lack of a blood-brain barrier allows it to detect toxins and trigger the protective reflex

of vomiting, making it a key target for antiemetic medications.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[E
metogenic Toxins in Blood] --> B(Area Postrema/CTZ); B --> C(Vomiting Center -

definition": "

The Argyll Robertson Pupil is a specific type of pupillary abnormality characterized by bilateral small
pupils that constrict when the patient focuses on a near object (accommodation reflex) but do <u>not</u> constrict when exposed

to bright light (light reflex). This phenomenon is known as light-near dissociation.

", "atAGlance

": "
  • Classic Mnemonic: Often called the \"prostitute's pupil\" because it \"accommodates but

does not react.\"
  • Pathophysiology: The lesion is thought to be in the pretectal nucleus
</mark> in the superior colliculus of the midbrain, which interrupts the afferent limb of the pupillary light reflex pathway before
it reaches the Edinger-Westphal nuclei bilaterally. The pathway for accommodation, which is more complex and involves the

cerebral cortex, is spared.
  • Classic Association: It is a highly specific sign of late-stage,
or tertiary, <mark>neurosyphilis</mark>, particularly [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]].
• Other Causes: While classic for syphilis, it can also be seen in other conditions causing midbrain lesions, such as diabetes mellitus

or Parinaud syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with ataxia, a positive Romberg sign,
and pupils that accommodate but don't react to light is a classic presentation of [[71daebd6|tabes

dorsalis]] due to neurosyphilis.", "takeAway": "

The
Argyll Robertson Pupil is a pathognomonic sign of neurosyphilis, representing a selective lesion
in the midbrain that disconnects the pupillary light reflex pathway while preserving the separate, cortically-driven accommodation pathway,

resulting in the classic light-near dissociation.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Light]
--> B(Optic Nerve); B --> C(Pretectal Nucleus); C --x Lesion; C
--x D(Edinger-Westphal Nucleus); E[Near Object] --> F(Visual Cortex); F --> G

": { "definition": "

Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) is a nonsteroidal
anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that irreversibly inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX) enzymes, primarily used at low doses for its anti

platelet effects in the prevention of cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events.

", "atAGlance": "
Mechanism of Action: Irreversibly acetylates and inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2.
Its antiplatelet effect is due to inhibition of COX-1 in platelets, which blocks the synthesis of <mark>Th
romboxane A2 (TXA2), a potent promoter of platelet aggregation.
• Clinical Use (Neurology): Used for secondary prevention of [[c5da3c57|ischemic stroke]] and
[[623ba776|transient ischemic attacks (TIAs)]]. It is a cornerstone of anti

platelet therapy.
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress (gastritis, ulcers), bleeding, tinnitus (

a sign of toxicity), and Reye syndrome in children with viral illness.
  • Reye Syndrome: A rare
but severe condition of acute encephalopathy and fatty liver failure in children given aspirin for a viral infection (e.g., influenza,

varicella). Aspirin is contraindicated in children for this reason (except in Kawasaki disease).
  • USMLE Tip
: The irreversibility of aspirin's effect on platelets is key. Since platelets lack a nucleus, they cannot synthesize
new COX enzyme, so the antiplatelet effect lasts for the life of the platelet (~7-10 days).

", "takeAway": "

Aspirin's primary role in stroke prevention stems from its unique ability
to <u>irreversibly</u> inhibit platelet COX-1, effectively silencing thromboxane A<sub>2</sub> production for

the platelet's entire lifespan and thus reducing the risk of thrombotic occlusion.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[A
spirin] --Irreversibly Inhibits--> B(Platelet COX-1); B --x C(Ar
achidonic Acid -> Thromboxane A2); C --x D(Platelet Aggregation); D --x E(Throm

      "
Asterixis is a type of negative myoclonus characterized by a brief, flapping tremor of the hands,
typically elicited by having the patient extend their arms and dorsiflex their wrists. It is a classic sign of metabolic encephalopathy.</

p>", "atAGlance": "
  • Elicitation: The patient holds their arms out
with wrists extended ('stop traffic' pose). The 'flap' is a sudden, brief loss of postural tone, causing the hands to drop,

followed by a rapid, jerky return to the original position.
  • Pathophysiology: It is not a true
tremor but a failure of the brain to maintain a sustained posture, thought to be due to abnormal function of the diencephalic

motor centers that regulate posture and tone.
  • Classic Association: Most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy

due to liver failure, where high ammonia levels are neurotoxic.
  • Other Causes: Can
also be seen in other metabolic encephalopathies, including uremia (renal failure), CO<sub>2</sub> narcosis (hyper

capnia), and drug intoxication. It is also a feature of [[wilson_disease|Wilson disease]].
  • USMLE Tip:
A patient with a history of cirrhosis who presents with confusion and a 'flapping tremor' of the hands has hepatic

encephalopathy. The tremor is asterixis.", "takeAway": "

Asterixis is a '
negative' movement disorder‚Äîa brief lapse in muscle tone rather than an active contraction‚Äîthat serves as a crucial physical exam

finding for metabolic encephalopathies, most classically hepatic encephalopathy from hyperammonemia.

", "mermaid": ""

definition": "

Astigmatism is a common refractive error of the eye where vision is blurred or distorted at
all distances. It occurs when the cornea or lens has an irregular, non-spherical curvature, causing light rays to focus

at multiple points rather than a single point on the retina.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Path
ophysiology: The cornea, which should be shaped like a sphere, is instead shaped more like a football (tor

ic). This causes light entering the eye to have different focal points in different planes (e.g., vertical vs. horizontal).
  • Symptoms

: Blurred or distorted vision, eye strain, and headaches.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosed during a standard

eye exam using a phoropter and keratometer.
  • Correction: Corrected with eyeglasses or contact lenses that have
a <mark>cylindrical lens</mark> to compensate for the irregular curvature. It can also be corrected with refractive

surgery (e.g., LASIK).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from other refractive errors:
[[myopia|myopia]] (nearsightedness) and [[hyperopia|hyperopia]] (farsightedness)
are caused by the length of the eyeball relative to its focusing power, while astigmatism is caused by an irregularly shaped cornea or

lens.", "takeAway": "

Astigmatism is a refractive error caused by an
asymmetrically shaped cornea or lens, which acts like a warped mirror, scattering light to multiple focal points and resulting in blurred

"type": "is_a_type_of",
        "to": "refractive_error"

"content": { "definition": "

Astrocytes are the most abundant type of glial cell
in the central nervous system. These star-shaped cells perform a wide variety of essential supportive and homeostatic functions for neurons, and

are the origin of the most common primary brain tumor in adults, [[b6bbd0bc|glioblastoma]].

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Functions: Physical support for neurons, repair (gliosis/
scar formation), component of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]] (via foot processes), removal of excess

neurotransmitters (especially glutamate), and maintenance of the ionic environment.
  • Histological Marker: They are identified

by their expression of Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein (GFAP), an intermediate filament protein.
  • Reactive
Gliosis: In response to CNS injury (e.g., stroke, trauma), astrocytes proliferate and hypertrophy to form a <

mark>glial scar, which walls off the damaged area but can also impede axonal regeneration.
  • Tum
or Origin: Astrocytes are the cell of origin for astrocytomas, including the highly malignant [[b6bbd0bc|glio

blastoma]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember GFAP as the key marker for astrocytes and astrocytic tumors. The

formation of a glial scar by astrocytes is the CNS equivalent of fibrosis in other tissues.", "takeAway": "

Ast
rocytes are the indispensable 'housekeepers' of the CNS, providing structural, metabolic, and homeostatic support to neurons, forming
the blood-brain barrier, and orchestrating the glial scar response to injury, but they can also give rise to the

most aggressive brain tumors.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Astrocyte]; A --> B(Physical
Support); A --> C(Blood-Brain Barrier); A --> D(Neurotransmitter Uptake); A --> E(
Ion Buffering); A --> F(Repair/Gliosis); A --Neoplastic Transformation--> G(Astrocytoma/

content": { "definition": "

Ataxia is a neurological sign consisting of a lack of voluntary
coordination of muscle movements, leading to a clumsy, unsteady gait and impaired balance. It can be caused by damage to the cerebellum, the

vestibular system, or sensory pathways.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Cerebellar Ataxia: Ca

used by damage to the cerebellum.
- Truncal Ataxia: Affects the midline, causing

an unsteady, wide-based ('drunken sailor') gait. Associated with lesions of the cerebellar vermis.
- L
imb Ataxia: Affects the extremities, causing dysmetria (overshooting/undershooting targets) and intention

tremor. Associated with lesions of the cerebellar hemispheres.
  • Sensory Ataxia: Caused by loss of proprio
ception, typically from damage to the [[e7f5cbbe|dorsal columns]] of the spinal cord or peripheral nerves
. Patients have a positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]] (worsening of balance
with eyes closed) and a stomping gait. Seen in [[71daebd6|tabes dorsalis]] and

[[6f5bea90|subacute combined degeneration]].
  • Vestibular Ataxia: Caused by

dysfunction of the vestibular system. Associated with vertigo, nystagmus, and nausea.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiating
the type of ataxia is key. A positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]] points
to a sensory (dorsal column) cause, not a cerebellar cause. Patients with cerebellar ataxia are unsteady with their

eyes open or closed.", "takeAway": "

Ataxia is a sign
of discoordination that can be localized by its characteristics: truncal and limb incoordination points to the cerebellum, a

positive Romberg sign points to sensory loss in the dorsal columns, and associated vertigo points to the vestibular system.

", "

"type": "is_a_symptom_of",

content": { "definition": "

Athetosis is a type of involuntary movement disorder characterized by slow, writhing,
snake-like movements, particularly affecting the distal extremities (fingers and hands). It is a symptom of damage to the [[

ed462927|basal ganglia]].

", "atAGlance": "
  • Description
: Slow, twisting, and writhing movements that are continuous and non-rhythmic. It is often described as being

'snake-like.'
  • Lesion Location: Caused by lesions in the [[ed46292

7|basal ganglia]], particularly the striatum (caudate and putamen).
  • Classic Association: A
thetosis is a characteristic feature of [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]], where it often co-occurs with chorea (ter

med choreoathetosis).
  • Other Causes: Can also be seen in conditions like cerebral palsy.
• USMLE Tip: When you see a description of slow, writhing, 'snake-like' movements of
the fingers in a patient with other signs of a basal ganglia disorder (like chorea or dementia), think of athetosis,
especially in the context of [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]].", "takeAway

": "

Athetosis is a specific and visually distinct sign of basal ganglia dysfunction, representing a failure of motor
control that manifests as slow, ceaseless, writhing movements, most classically seen in [[ffd7e743|Hunting

"content": { "definition": "

Atonic seizures, also known as \"drop attacks
\" or \"drop seizures,\" are a type of generalized seizure characterized by a sudden loss of muscle tone, causing the individual to collapse

to the ground. The loss of consciousness is typically very brief.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Clinical
Presentation: A sudden, complete loss of postural muscle tone lasting 1-2 seconds. This can cause the head to drop

, the jaw to slacken, or the entire body to fall limply to the floor.
  • Risk of Injury: There

is a high risk of head and facial injuries from the sudden falls. Patients may need to wear protective helmets.
  • Associated
Syndromes: While they can occur in various epilepsy syndromes, atonic seizures are a hallmark feature of Lennox-

Gastaut syndrome, a severe form of childhood epilepsy.
  • EEG Findings: The EEG may show brief

, generalized spike-and-wave discharges followed by diffuse slow waves.
  • USMLE Tip: A vignette
describing a child with developmental delay who has multiple seizure types, including sudden falls leading to injury, is highly suggestive of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome,

with atonic seizures being a key component.", "takeAway": "

Atonic seizures are dramatic
'drop attacks' caused by a sudden, global loss of muscle tone, posing a significant risk of injury and often signaling

a severe underlying epilepsy syndrome like Lennox-Gastaut.

", "mermaid": "" }, "connections":

": "

Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent

used in anesthesia to induce skeletal muscle relaxation and paralysis, facilitating endotracheal intubation and surgical procedures.

", "at

AGlance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: Acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction,

preventing [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] from binding and causing muscle contraction.
  • Met
abolism: Undergoes Hoffmann elimination, a spontaneous, non-enzymatic degradation at physiological pH and

temperature. This makes its metabolism independent of liver or kidney function.
  • Clinical Use: Ideal for patients with <

mark>renal or hepatic failure because its elimination does not depend on these organs.
  • Adverse Effects: Can cause histamine
release, leading to hypotension, flushing, and bronchoconstriction. Its metabolite, laudanosine, can lower the seizure threshold,

but this is rarely clinically significant.
  • Reversal: The neuromuscular blockade can be reversed by [[acetylcholinesterase_
inhibitors|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., neostigmine), which increase the concentration of acetylcholine

in the synaptic cleft to outcompete the blocker.
  • USMLE Tip: The key feature of at
racurium (and its stereoisomer, cisatracurium) is its Hoffmann elimination, making it the neuromuscular blocker

of choice for patients with organ dysfunction.", "takeAway": "

Atrac
urium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker distinguished by its unique Hoffmann elimination pathway, a spontaneous chemical breakdown that makes it a

safe and predictable choice for inducing paralysis in patients with kidney or liver disease.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Atr
acurium] --Competitively Antagonizes--> B(Nicotinic ACh Receptors); B --x C(A
Ch Binding); C --x D(Muscle Contraction); A --Hoffmann Elimination--> E(Inactive Metabolites);"

": "

Atrophy is a cellular adaptation characterized by a decrease in the size of a cell, organ
, or tissue after it has reached its normal mature size. It results from a decrease in cell substance and can be either

physiologic or pathologic.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism: Atrophy occurs via
a decrease in protein synthesis and an increase in protein degradation. The main pathway for protein degradation is the <mark>ubiquitin-prote

asome pathway. It can also involve autophagy, where the cell digests its own components.
  • Causes

: Common causes include disuse, denervation, loss of endocrine stimulation, inadequate nutrition, and ischemia.
  • Neu
rologic Relevance (Denervation Atrophy): When a muscle loses its nerve supply (denervation), it undergoes rapid and profound atrophy

. This is a key sign of a lower motor neuron (LMN) lesion.
  • UMN
vs. LMN Lesions: Significant muscle atrophy is a hallmark of LMN lesions (e.g., polio
, [[4ed629f9|ALS]], peripheral nerve injury). In contrast, upper motor neuron (UMN

) lesions cause only mild disuse atrophy.
  • USMLE Tip: In a clinical vignette, the presence of marked
muscle wasting (atrophy) and fasciculations strongly points towards an LMN component of a disease process.",

"takeAway": "

Atrophy is a reduction in cell size and substance, most often driven by the
ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. In neurology, denervation atrophy is a critical sign that localizes a lesion to the lower

motor neuron, distinguishing it from upper motor neuron pathology.

", "mermaid": "" }, "connections

      "
itory anatomy and physiology describes the structures and mechanisms by which sound waves are collected, transmitted, transduced into neural signals, and processed

by the brain to produce the sensation of hearing.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Outer Ear: The

pinna and external auditory canal collect sound waves and funnel them to the tympanic membrane (eardrum).
  • Middle Ear
: An air-filled cavity containing the ossicles (malleus, incus, stapes). The ossicles amplify

the vibrations from the tympanic membrane and transmit them to the oval window of the inner ear.
  • Inner Ear: The [[
001c359f|cochlea]], a fluid-filled, snail-shaped structure, contains the organ

of Corti. Vibrations from the stapes create pressure waves in the cochlear fluid.
  • Transduction: These
pressure waves cause the basilar membrane to vibrate at specific locations depending on the frequency (tonotopy). High frequencies vibrate the base, low frequencies vibrate
the apex. This vibration bends the stereocilia of hair cells in the organ of Corti, opening ion channels and generating a

neural signal.
  • Neural Pathway: The signal travels from the hair cells via the cochlear nerve (part
of CN VIII) to the cochlear nuclei in the brainstem, then through a complex pathway (superior olive, lateral
lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate nucleus of the thalamus) to the [[d24b

6af6|auditory cortex]] in the temporal lobe.", "takeAway": "

The
auditory system is a remarkable transducer, converting mechanical energy (sound waves) into mechanical vibration (ossicles), then into hydraulic

waves (cochlear fluid), and finally into electrical signals (hair cells) that the brain interprets as sound.

", "mermaid
": "graph TD; A[Sound Waves] --> B(Outer Ear); B --> C(Tympanic Membrane); C --> D(Middle
Ear Ossicles); D --> E(Oval Window); E --> F(Cochlear Fluid); F --> G(
Basilar Membrane Vibration); G --> H(Hair Cell Transduction); H --> I(CN VIII); I --> J(Brain);

      "Cerebral Cortex"
region of the cerebral cortex responsible for processing auditory information. It is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe and

includes the primary auditory cortex (Brodmann areas 41 and 42) and surrounding auditory association areas.

", "

atAGlance": "
  • Location: Superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe.
  • Function
: The primary auditory cortex is responsible for the perception of basic sound characteristics like pitch and volume. The surrounding association areas,
including [[wernicke_area|Wernicke's area]] in the dominant hemisphere, are involved in the

interpretation and comprehension of complex sounds, particularly speech.
  • Thalamic Relay: It receives its primary input
from the <mark>medial geniculate nucleus (MGN)</mark> of the [[afc0a64

b|thalamus]]. Mnemonic: Medial = Music (hearing).
  • Ton
otopic Organization: The auditory cortex is organized tonotopically, meaning that different frequencies of sound are processed in different,
specific areas of the cortex, mirroring the organization of the [[001c359f|cochlea]].
USMLE Tip: A lesion in the primary auditory cortex does not typically cause complete deafness in one ear, as auditory
information from each ear is processed bilaterally in the brain. However, a lesion in [[wernicke_area|Wern
icke's area]] (an auditory association cortex) will cause receptive aphasia.", "takeAway": "
The Auditory Cortex is the final destination for sound processing in the brain, receiving signals from the medial geniculate nucleus and

interpreting them, with specialized areas like Wernicke's area in the dominant hemisphere being crucial for language comprehension.

", "mermaid
": "graph TD; A[Cochlea] --> B(CN VIII); B --> C(Brainstem Nucle

"content": { "definition": "

The Autonomic Nervous System (ANS) is the
division of the peripheral nervous system that controls involuntary bodily functions, such as heart rate, digestion, respiratory rate, and pup

illary response. It is subdivided into the sympathetic, parasympathetic, and enteric systems.

", "atAG

lance": "
  • Sympathetic Division: Mediates the \"fight or flight\" response. Preganglionic neurons are
short and release [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] onto nicotinic receptors in the paravertebral ganglia. Postgangl

ionic neurons are long and primarily release norepinephrine onto adrenergic receptors.
  • Parasympathetic Division: Mediates the \"rest
and digest\" response. Preganglionic neurons are long and release [[6a005559|acetylcholine]] onto nicotinic receptors
in ganglia near or within target organs. Postganglionic neurons are short and release [[6a005559

|acetylcholine]] onto muscarinic receptors.
  • CNS Control: The ANS is regulated by higher centers in the CNS
, including the [[89e86633|hypothalamus]] and the [[73ace3

57|limbic system]], which modulate autonomic outflow in response to emotional and environmental stimuli.
  • Clinical Relevance
: Autonomic dysregulation is a feature of many neurological disorders, including [[ed52e40b|Gu
illain-Barr√© syndrome]] (acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy), which can cause life-threatening cardiac

irregularities and blood pressure instability.
  • USMLE Tip: Understand the neurotransmitter/receptor pairings: All pre
ganglionic neurons use ACh (nicotinic). Parasympathetic postganglionic neurons use ACh (muscarinic). Most
sympathetic postganglionic neurons use norepinephrine (adrenergic), with the key exception being sweat glands (ACh, muscarinic).

", "takeAway": "

The Autonomic Nervous System maintains homeostasis through a balance of its
sympathetic ('gas pedal') and parasympathetic ('brake pedal') divisions, utilizing a two-neuron chain with distinct neurotransmitters

and receptor targets to exert involuntary control over virtually every organ system.

", "mermaid": "graph TD;
A[CNS] --> B(Preganglionic Neuron); B --ACh--> C(Autonomic Ganglion); C --NE

      "
>Axonal injury refers to damage to the axons of neurons, which can occur from trauma, ischemia, or neuro
degenerative processes. The neuronal response to injury and the potential for regeneration depend on whether the injury is in the central or peripheral nervous system.</

p>", "atAGlance": "
  • Wallerian Degeneration: The process of degeneration of
the axon <u>distal</u> to the site of injury. The axon disintegrates and its myelin sheath breaks down,

cleared by Schwann cells (PNS) or microglia (CNS).
  • Axonal Reaction (Central Chromatolysis): Changes
occurring in the neuronal cell body <u>proximal</u> to the injury. The cell body swells, the nucleus is displaced

to the periphery, and Nissl bodies disperse. This reflects an increase in protein synthesis for repair.
  • Diffuse
Axonal Injury (DAI): A severe form of traumatic brain injury caused by shearing forces from rapid acceleration/deceleration. It involves widespread

damage to axons in the white matter tracts. MRI shows multiple punctate hemorrhages. Often results in coma or persistent vegetative state.
  • Reg
eneration: Axonal regeneration is limited in the CNS due to inhibitory factors from oligodendrocytes and glial scar formation by astrocytes. Regeneration

is more successful in the PNS, guided by the remaining Schwann cells and endoneurial tube.
  • USMLE Tip:
Remember the key difference in response to injury: Wallerian degeneration occurs distal to the cut, while axonal reaction (chromatolysis) occurs in

the proximal cell body.", "takeAway": "

Axonal injury triggers a cascade of degenerative
and regenerative processes, with the outcome largely determined by the location; peripheral nerves have a significant capacity for regeneration guided by Schwann cells, whereas central nervous

system axons are largely unable to regenerate due to an inhibitory environment.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[
Axon Injury] --> B(Proximal Segment); B --> C(Axonal Reaction/Chromatolysis); A -->

antar Reflex)",

p>The Babinski reflex (or sign) is the dorsiflexion of the great toe and
fanning of the other toes in response to stroking the plantar surface of the foot. While a normal primitive reflex in infants,

its presence in an adult is a pathognomonic sign of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Technique: The sole of the foot is stroked with a blunt object from

the heel along the lateral aspect to the ball of the foot.
  • Normal Response (Adult): Plantar flexion (

downward curling) of the toes.
  • Abnormal Response (Babinski Sign): Extension (dorsiflexion) of the

great toe and fanning of the other toes.
  • Pathophysiology: The sign indicates damage to the cortic

ospinal tract, which normally suppresses this primitive reflex after infancy.
  • Clinical Significance: A positive Babinski sign is a key
physical exam finding that helps differentiate UMN lesions from LMN lesions. It is a sign of <mark>upper motor neuron damage

.
  • USMLE Tip: In an adult, a positive Babinski sign is always abnormal. It points
to a lesion anywhere along the corticospinal tract, from the motor cortex down to the spinal cord.", "takeAway

": "

The Babinski sign is a clinical indicator of corticospinal tract dysfunction, representing the re
-emergence of a primitive reflex that is normally suppressed by mature upper motor neurons; its presence in an adult is a definitive sign of a

      "S
skeletal muscle relaxant (antispasmodic) that functions as a GABA<sub>B</sub> receptor agonist, primarily used to treat

muscle spasticity.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: Acts
as an agonist at <mark>GABA<sub>B</sub> receptors</gmark> in the spinal cord. This activation
leads to hyperpolarization of motor neurons by increasing K<sup>+</sup> conductance, which reduces the release of excitatory neurotransmitters.
• Clinical Use: Treatment of spasticity associated with [[45dd6d19|multiple sclerosis]],
spinal cord injuries, and [[171ca00b|cerebral palsy]]. It is not typically used for acute

muscle spasms from injury.
  • Administration: Can be administered orally or intrathecally (directly into the CSF) via

a pump for severe spasticity.
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, drowsiness, dizziness, and muscle weakness.
Abrupt withdrawal of intrathecal baclofen can be life-threatening, causing high fever, rebound spasticity, and

seizures.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that baclofen acts on the 'back' (spinal
cord) at GABAB receptors. Differentiate its use for chronic spasticity from drugs like cyclobenzaprine used

for acute muscle spasms.", "takeAway": "

Baclofen effectively reduces chronic
muscle spasticity by mimicking GABA's inhibitory effects at GABA<sub>B</sub> receptors specifically within the spinal cord, thereby damp

ening the hyperactive reflexes that cause stiffness and spasms.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Bac
lofen] --> B(Activates GABA-B Receptors in Spinal Cord); B --> C(‚Üë K+
Conductance); C --> D(Hyperpolarization of Motor Neurons); D --> E(‚Üì Spasticity);"

"content": { "definition": "

Barbiturates (e.g., phenobarbital, pent
obarbital, thiopental) are a class of sedative-hypnotic drugs that act as central nervous system depressants by

enhancing the effects of the neurotransmitter GABA.

", "atAGlance": "
  • Mechanism of Action: Bind
to the GABA<sub>A</sub> receptor at a different site than GABA or benzodiazepines. They increase the <mark><u>
duration of chloride channel opening. Mnemonic: Barbidurates increase the duration.
• Clinical Use: Formerly used for anxiety and insomnia but now largely replaced by benzodiazepines due to a worse

safety profile. Current uses include:
- Anticonvulsant: [[phenobarbital]] for

seizures.
- Anesthesia: Thiopental for induction of anesthesia.
  • Adverse
Effects: Significant CNS and respiratory depression, which can be fatal in overdose and is potentiated by alcohol. High potential for dependence

and abuse. Induces cytochrome P450 enzymes, leading to numerous drug interactions.
  • Contraindication: Absolutely

contraindicated in patients with porphyria, as they induce Œ¥-ALA synthase.
  • USMLE Tip: The
key difference from benzodiazepines is the mechanism (duration vs. frequency) and the lack of a ceiling effect on CNS depression, making
overdose much more dangerous. There is no specific antidote for barbiturate overdose; treatment is supportive.", "takeAway

": "

Barbiturates are potent CNS depressants that enhance GABAergic inhibition by prolonging the opening
of chloride channels, but their narrow therapeutic index and high risk of fatal respiratory depression have relegated them to niche uses like seizure

control and anesthesia induction.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Barbiturate] --> B(B
inds to GABA-A Receptor); B --> C(‚Üë Duration of Cl- Channel Opening); C --> D(‚Üë Cl

      "
a group of subcortical nuclei in the forebrain that are crucial for motor control, particularly in selecting and initiating voluntary movements, while

suppressing unwanted movements. They also play a role in procedural learning, habit formation, and emotion.

", "atAG

lance": "
  • Components: The main components are the Striatum (caudate nucleus
+ putamen), Globus Pallidus (internal and external segments), Subthalamic Nucleus,

and Substantia Nigra (pars compacta and pars reticulata).
  • Function: The basal ganglia modulate motor output

from the cortex via feedback loops. They do not directly connect to the spinal cord.
  • Direct Pathway: Facilit
ates movement. Cortical activation stimulates the striatum, which inhibits the globus pallidus internus (GPi), thereby
disinhibiting the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]] and allowing it to excite the motor

cortex.
  • Indirect Pathway: Inhibits movement. This more complex loop ultimately results in stimulation of the GPi, which increases

inhibition of the [[afc0a64b|thalamus]], thus suppressing cortical activity.
  • Pathology

: Lesions in the basal ganglia lead to movement disorders.
- [[58c8ea03|Parkinson disease
]]: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta leads to bradykinesia and tremor (hyp

okinetic).
- [[ffd7e743|Huntington disease]]: Degeneration of the striatum leads to chore

a (hyperkinetic).
- Hemiballismus: Lesion of the subthalamic nucleus leads to wild

, flinging movements.", "takeAway": "

The Basal Ganglia function
as a sophisticated 'gatekeeper' for motor commands, using a balance between a 'go' (direct) pathway and a
'no-go' (indirect) pathway to fine-tune voluntary movement; disruption of this balance is the fundamental cause

of movement disorders like Parkinson's and Huntington's disease.

", "mermaid": "graph LR; A[C
ortex] --> B(Striatum); B --|Direct Pathway (Go)|--> C(‚Üì GPi/SN
r Inhibition); C --> D(‚Üë Thalamic Excitation); D --> A; B --|Indirect Pathway (No
-Go)|--> E(‚Üë GPi/SNr Inhibition); E --> F(‚Üì Thalamic Excitation); F -->

content": { "definition": "

The Basal Nucleus of Meynert is a group of neurons
located in the substantia innominata of the basal forebrain. It is the primary source of cholinergic ([[6a005559|

acetylcholine]]) innervation to the entire cerebral cortex, playing a vital role in cognitive functions like memory and attention.

",

"atAGlance": "
  • Location: Basal forebrain, part of the substantia innominata.
• Neurotransmitter: Synthesizes and releases [[6a005559|acetylcholine (

ACh)]].
  • Projections: Provides widespread cholinergic projections to the neocortex and hippocampus.
  • Function

: Modulates cortical excitability, arousal, attention, and is critical for learning and memory formation.
  • Clinical Relevance: There
is significant degeneration and loss of cholinergic neurons in the Basal Nucleus of Meynert in <mark>[[7
7ae6148|Alzheimer disease]]</mark>. This loss of cortical ACh is a major contributor to the cognitive

and memory deficits seen in the disease.
  • USMLE Tip: The degeneration of the Basal Nucleus of Mey
nert and the resulting cholinergic deficit is a key pathophysiological feature of [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] and
is the rationale for using [[acetylcholinesterase_inhibitors|acetylcholinesterase inhibitors]] (e.g., [[
47d0372e|donepezil]]) as a symptomatic treatment.", "

takeAway": "

The Basal Nucleus of Meynert is the brain's main cholinergic hub
for the cortex; its profound degeneration in [[77ae6148|Alzheimer disease]] leads to a cortical

acetylcholine deficit that underlies the hallmark cognitive decline of the disease.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A
[Basal Nucleus of Meynert] --ACh Projections--> B(Cerebral Cortex & Hippocampus); B

      "Blood-
ement membrane is a thin, specialized layer of the extracellular matrix that surrounds cerebral capillaries and, along with astrocyte foot processes and endothelial

tight junctions, forms a critical component of the [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].

", "atAG

lance": "
  • Composition: Primarily composed of Type IV collagen, laminin, and proteoglycans.
Function: Provides structural support to the capillary endothelium and acts as a selective filter, regulating the passage of molecules from the blood into the brain

parenchyma.
  • Role in Blood-Brain Barrier: The basement membrane, together with endothelial [[tight_junctions|

tight junctions]] and astrocyte end-feet, creates the highly restrictive [[dd47b9cc|blood-brain barrier]].
  • Path
ology: Thickening of the basement membrane is a feature of chronic hyperglycemia in diabetes, contributing to microvascular complications like
[[73b00ab0|diabetic retinopathy]]. In [[goodpasture_syndrome|Goodpasture syndrome]], auto

antibodies target Type IV collagen in the basement membranes of the kidneys and lungs.
  • USMLE Tip: The
three key components of the blood-brain barrier are: 1) Tight junctions between non-fenestrated endothelial cells, 2)

The basement membrane, and 3) Astrocyte foot processes.", "takeAway": "

The
basement membrane of CNS capillaries is a crucial structural and functional element of the [[dd47b9cc|blood

-brain barrier]], acting as both scaffolding and a selective filter to maintain the tightly controlled environment of the brain.

"content": { "definition": "

The Basilar Artery is a critical artery at
the base of the brain, formed by the union of the two vertebral arteries. It ascends along the anterior surface of the pons and is

a key component of the posterior circulation, supplying the brainstem, cerebellum, and occipital lobes.

", "

atAGlance": "
  • Formation: Formed by the confluence of the left and right vertebral arteries at the pont

omedullary junction.
  • Branches: Gives rise to the [[3c075343|anterior inferior
cerebellar artery (AICA)]], superior cerebellar artery (SCA), and numerous small pontine arteries. It terminates by

bifurcating into the two [[b6a2cc31|posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs)]].
  • Terr
itory Supplied: Brainstem (pons, midbrain), cerebellum, and via its terminal branches (PCAs), the occipital and

inferior temporal lobes.
  • Stroke Syndromes:
    - Basilar Artery Occlusion:
Can be catastrophic, leading to \"locked-in syndrome\" if the ventral pons is infar

cted bilaterally. This causes quadriplegia and mutism, with preserved consciousness and vertical eye movements.
- Top
of the Basilar Syndrome: Embolic occlusion of the distal basilar artery affects the midbrain, thalamus, and temporal

/occipital lobes, causing visual and behavioral disturbances with minimal motor deficits.
  • USMLE Tip: A
stroke causing quadriplegia but sparing consciousness and vertical eye movements is pathognomonic for basilar artery occlusion leading to locked-in syndrome.

", "takeAway": "

The Basilar Artery is the central trunk of the posterior
circulation; its occlusion can lead to devastating brainstem strokes, most notably the 'locked-in syndrome,' which severs the brain'

s motor output while leaving consciousness intact.

", "mermaid": "graph TD; A[Vertebral Arter
ies] --> B(Basilar Artery); B --> C(Pontine Arteries); B --> D(A

": "

REM Sleep Behavior Disorder (RBD) is a parasomnia characterized by the loss of normal muscle

atonia during REM sleep, leading to the physical enactment of vivid, often violent or action-filled dreams.

", "atAGlance

": "
  • Pathophysiology: Failure of the brainstem mechanisms (particularly in the pons) that normally induce

muscle paralysis during REM sleep.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients may shout, punch, kick, or jump out of bed during sleep

, corresponding to the content of their dreams. This can result in injury to the patient or their bed partner.
  • Classic
Association: RBD is a very strong predictor of future neurodegenerative disease, particularly Œ±-synucleinopathies

.
  • Associated Diseases: A majority of patients with idiopathic RBD will eventually develop [[58c8ea03|
Parkinson disease]], [[db2f16e5|Lewy body dementia]], or multiple system atrophy, often years

or decades after the onset of RBD.
  • USMLE Tip: An older male patient who reports acting out violent
dreams and has injured his spouse during sleep should raise immediate suspicion for REM Sleep Behavior Disorder, which should be considered a prod

romal sign of Parkinson disease or Lewy body dementia.", "takeAway": "

REM Sleep
Behavior Disorder is more than just a sleep disturbance; it is a critical early warning sign of an underlying Œ±-synucleinopathy, where
the failure to paralyze muscles during dreaming precedes the onset of motor and cognitive symptoms of diseases like Parkinson's by many

_a_prodromal_sign_of",

    "classificationPath": [
